column8: synthetic biology is considered the engineering approach to building molecular systems. It enables the creation of entirely new molecular functionality in a modular and systematic fashion. column1: Group Leader - Structural or Molecular Systems Biology;"About the team/job
The Structural and Computational Biology (SCB) Unit at EMBL Heidelberg pursues an ambitious and cross-disciplinary research program in integrated structural and computational systems biology
column2: bridging between temporal and spatial scales. The SCB Unit seeks to recruit a highly motivated group leader in the area of structural or molecular systems biology to address fundamental questions in life sciences.

column1: Your role
Establish an independent and innovative research programme. The SCB Unit is interested in attracting candidates that pursue experimental or computational approaches
column2: which can contribute to or interface with integrated structural biology. Research areas can be diverse including chemical biology
column4: biophysics
column5: proteomics
column6: metabolomics
column7: synthetic biology
column8: modelling and simulation of biological systems. The research should extend or enrich structural systems biology
column9: a broad concept that the unit is pursuing
column10: in conjunction with a strong computational biology programme.

column1: In line with EMBL’s scientific programme from Molecules to Ecosystems
column2: the SCB Unit is also interested in candidates that have research programs related to EMBL’s transversal themes; for example
column3: the SCB Unit has already considerable strengths in Planetary Biology and Microbial Ecosystems. The future group leader will be embedded in the multidisciplinary and collaborative environment of EMBL
column4: which provides many opportunities for interaction with other research groups.

column1: You have
The ambition to work on fundamental biological questions
column2: which implies both
column3: biological discoveries or methodological advances. Furthermore
column4: your research complements and synergizes with the activities of the SCB Unit and the whole of EMBL. You should therefore demonstrate a strong motivation to work in the collaborative and multidisciplinary environment of EMBL.

column1: In addition
column2: you should be dedicated to develop effective relationships and to provide leadership and guidance to team members. The ability to work independently and to participate in a collaborative team effort is desirable
column3: as is a pro-active and positive problem-solving mind-set.

column1: EMBL’s future scientific directions...
EMBL’s new program
column2: Molecules to Ecosystems
column3: includes a vision to advance our understanding of ecosystems at the molecular level
column4: applying expertise in molecular biology to study life in its natural context. New research areas will focus on applying experimental
column5: computational and theoretical approaches to study at multiple levels (molecules
column6: cells
column7: tissues and populations) how organisms interact with each other and respond to environmental change. SCB will be happy to host structural or molecular systems biology activities related to the new transversal themes.

column1: • Planetary Biology – aiming to understand how microbes
column2: plants
column3: and animals interact with each other and with their abiotic environments at the molecular level.

column1: • Microbial Ecosystems – studying microorganisms
column2: how they live in communities and interact with their environments

column1: • Infection Biology - unravelling new strategies to treat infections by studying pathogens
column2: their molecular machineries
column4: and their ability to spread in populations and across hosts.

column1: • Human Ecosystems – applying computational and experimental approaches to reveal the impact of the environment on human health and physiology
column2: both at the individual and the population level.

column1: • Theory – using modelling
column2: mathematical reasoning
column3: and conceptual approaches to study complex and dynamic biological systems.

column1: Why join us

EMBL appoints group leaders from early on in their career and provides a very supportive environment for your first independent position in order to achieve your research goals. The initial ""Lead your Lab"" management training is provided for all incoming group leaders.

The SCB Unit at EMBL offers access to an outstanding integrated structural biology environment that includes a particularly well equipped cryo-electron microscopy facility. The Unit also interacts closely with the EMBL Imaging Centre that offers access to a broad spectrum of electron and light microscopy technologies with special emphasis on correlative approaches. Further information about research in the SCB Unit and at EMBL can be found at the EMBL web page.
EMBL is curiosity-driven
column2: community-oriented and international. As an inclusive
column4: we believe that diversity enables us to collaborate more effectively and be innovative in our approaches. We are
column5: therefore
column6: committed to creating an inclusive and flexible culture - one where everyone can realise their full potential and make a positive contribution to our organisation.

column1: We encourage applications from individuals who can complement our existing team – we believe that success is built on having teams whose backgrounds and personal experiences reflect the diversity of the populations that our science serves. We actively encourage applications from all genders and cultures
column2: ethnic groups and all demographics to help us avoid perpetuating biases and oversights at this transformational point in our people strategy.

column1: EMBL offers attractive conditions and benefits appropriate to an international research organisation with a very collegial and family-friendly working environment. Competitive salary and social security benefits
column2: financial support for relocation
column4: professional development
column5: an on-site nursery
column6: canteen and other staff facilities make EMBL a great place to work.

We are Europe’s flagship research laboratory for the life sciences – an intergovernmental organisation performing scientific research in disciplines including molecular biology

column1: Postdoc position (m/f/x) on engineering the membrane electron transport...;"The Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research (UFZ) with its 1
column2: 100 employees has gained an

column1: excellent reputation as an international competence centre for environmental sciences. We are part of
the largest scientific organisation in Germany
column2: the Helmholtz association. Our mission: Our research

column1: seeks to find a balance between social development and the long-term protection of our natural
resources.
Hydrogen will play a key role in decarbonizing our society and sustaining our future. Biophotovoltaics (BPV)
column2: which exploits the natural oxygenic photosystem in a bioelectrochemcial system
column3: aims to dilver a sustainble solution for hydrogen production in the future. It provides unique benefits in terms of the energy and resource demands and also it can potentially make H2 production as a carbon-sink process since the oxygenic photomicroorganism (e.g. cyanobacteria) use CO2 as the carbon source for growth and maintainance. Within the newly BMBF funded Nachwuchsgruppenprojekt BioPV4H2
column4: we aim to gain a holistic understanding the BPV process from both biological and technological aspects
column5: and thus to promote rational design and development of this technique for future application. To realize the proposed ambitious goals
column6: I am seeking an enthusiastic synthetic biologist to fill a full time postdoc position funded by this project. The main task of this position is to engineer the membrane electron transfer pathways of cyanobacteria in BPV using synthetic biology tools
column7: in order to facilitate the electron transfer rate from the photosystem to the external electron sink. The successfully candidate will have the support to establish and lead the synthetic biology platform in the group
column8: and will be strongly supported to develop his/her research profile for the next scientific career move
column9: including but not limited to further training

column1: Postdoc position (m/f/x) on engineering the membrane electron transport pathway in Synechocystis

column1: • Developing the synthetic biology methods for bacterial membrane protein expression and knock-down/out;
• Introducing heterologous membrane reductase to extract electrons from cellular electron transport chain;
• Characterizing the microbial physiology and behaviors;
• Communicating with our project partners and also involved in preparing the strategic plan of the project;
• Co-supervising PhD/Master/bachelor students;
• Presenting project progress at international scientific conferences;
• Writing progress report
column2: and publishing project results in high-ranked scientific journals;

• PhD in molecular biology

column1: PhD Position (m/f/d) | Alkaloid Biosynthesis
column2: Evolution and Engineering in...;"The department of Natural Product Biosynthesis (Prof. Dr. Sarah E. O’Connor) at the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology in Jena invites highly motivated candidates to apply for a 3-year PhD position to study alkaloid biosynthesis
column3: evolution and engineering in medicinal plants.

column1: Project description
Plants produce countless chemically diverse natural products
column2: or specialized metabolites. Alkaloids are a type of natural product that are widely used as medicines. If we discover the biosynthetic genes and enzymes that are responsible for the production of these medicinally important alkaloids
column3: then we can use synthetic biology or engineering approaches to enable better access to these medicines. Ipecac alkaloids have been widely used pharmacological agents for many years. Interestingly
column4: these compounds occur in two evolutionary distant plants suggesting that the biosynthetic pathways evolved independently; in other words
column5: nature developed two different biosynthetic pathways for these molecules. The aim of this PhD project is to discover the genes of the biosynthetic pathways of ipecac alkaloids in these two distantly related medicinal plant species. Then
column6: the pathways can be compared
column7: contrasted
column8: and recombined using state of the art plant-based production platforms. The PhD candidate will use cutting edge metabolomics and transcriptomics approaches to identify enzyme candidates
column10: characterize active enzymes in vitro and in vivo and reconstitute both natural and synthetic pathways";MPI for Chemical Ecology;PhD;"https://www.google.com/search?q=job+offers+synthetic+biology&oq=job+offers+synthetic+biology&ibp=htl;jobs&sa=X#htivrt=jobs&htidocid=LrQ99F_o3xYAAAAAAAAAAA%3D%3D&fpstate=tldetail";2022-08-08;2022-08-28;Jena

column1: Postdoc position (m/f/x) on engineering the membrane electron transport...;"The Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research (UFZ) with its 1
employees has gained an excellent reputation as an international competence
centre for environmental sciences. We are part of the largest scientific
organisation in Germany
column2: the Helmholtz association. Our mission: Our research

column1: seeks to find a balance between social development and the long-term
protection of our natural resources.
Hydrogen will play a key role in decarbonizing our society and sustaining our
future. Biophotovoltaics (BPV)
column2: which exploits the natural oxygenic

column1: photosystem in a bioelectrochemcial system
column2: aims to dilver a sustainble

column1: solution for hydrogen production in the future. It provides unique benefits in
terms of the energy and resource demands and also it can potentially make H2
production as a carbon-sink process since the oxygenic photomicroorganism
(e.g. cyanobacteria) use CO2 as the carbon source for growth and
maintainance. Within the newly BMBF funded Nachwuchsgruppenprojekt
BioPV4H2
column2: we aim to gain a holistic understanding the BPV process from

column1: both biological and technological aspects
column2: and thus to promote rational design

column1: and development of this technique for future application. To realize the
proposed ambitious goals
column2: I am seeking an enthusiastic synthetic biologist to

column1: fill a full time postdoc position funded by this project. The main task of
this position is to engineer the membrane electron transfer pathways of
cyanobacteria in BPV using synthetic biology tools
column2: in order to facilitate the

column1: electron transfer rate from the photosystem to the external electron sink. The
successfully candidate will have the support to establish and lead the
synthetic biology platform in the group

including but not limited to further training
column2: international conference and

column1: networking.

pathway in Synechocystis

column1: (The initial phase of employment will be 1 year

The successful candidate will develop and lead the synthetic biology platform
and work closely with the PhD students and also our project partners (e.g.
Prof. Victor de Lorenzo and Prof. Peter Lindblad) to drive the research
progress of the respective working tasks. Particularly your tasks will
include:
• Developing the synthetic biology methods for bacterial membrane protein
expression and knock-down/out;
• Introducing heterologous membrane reductase to extract electrons from
cellular electron transport chain;
• Characterizing the microbial physiology and behaviors;
• Communicating with our project partners and also involved in preparing the
strategic plan of the project;
• Co-supervising PhD/Master/bachelor students;
• Presenting project progress at international scientific conferences;
